description.p: This is a reference for writing Lua scripts to draw heads-up displays (HUDs) in Aleph One.
This is not a reference for Lua itself - see lua.org for that.

A Lua script can ask for the engine to load collections it might otherwise not load; for instance, in order to be able to draw defender and compiler shapes during a level that might not have them otherwise, add the indices for those collections to the global table CollectionsUsed:

function.name: init
function.description: when a game session is started (after leaving the main menu)

function.name: cleanup
function.description: when a game session is completed (before returning to the main menu)

function.name: resize
function.description: when the window size changes in the middle of a game (with the F1/F2 keys)

function.name: draw
function.note: all screen drawing must be called from this trigger
the screen is cleared before each frame

description.p: There are numerous tables (technically, userdata) defined in Aleph One which scripts can use to access objects in the game. A complete list is below.

In a real Lua table, you can set any field you want. In order to help troubleshooting, Aleph One's userdata tables will only accept the fields listed in the documentation below. However, by prepending an underscore, custom fields can be indexed. These custom fields will be associated with the object until it is destroyed.

Aleph One installs a set of boolean functions that can be used to recognize each of the userdata table types. For example, is_font(Fonts[1]) returns true. Each of these functions begins with the "is_" prefix.

table.name: color
table.description: Colors are standard Lua tables; you don't need to call a new() method to create them. Colors have four fields, accessed by name or number. If a field is missing, it is assumed to be 1, which allows you to write opaque colors as {r, g, b}.

variable.name: r
variable.description: red component, from 0 to 1

variable.name: g
variable.description: green component, from 0 to 1

variable.name: b
variable.description: blue component, from 0 to 1

variable.name: a
variable.description: alpha component (opacity), from 0 to 1

variable.name: width
variable.description: width of the available screen area

variable.name: height
variable.description: height of the available screen area

variable.name: fix_h_not_v
variable.description: whether horizontal or vertical FOV is adjusted as aspect ratio changes

variable.name: active
variable.description: whether crosshairs are visible

variable.name: lua_hud
variable.description: whether the Lua HUD script draws the crosshairs

variable.name: renderer
variable.description: which renderer is in use

variable.name: map_active
variable.description: whether the overhead map is currently displayed

variable.name: map_overlay_active
variable.description: whether the "Overlay Map" preference is enabled

variable.name: term_active
variable.description: whether a terminal is currently displayed

variable.name: hud_size_preference
variable.description: current preference setting for HUD size (normal, double, largest)

variable.name: term_size_preference
variable.description: current preference setting for terminal size (normal, double, largest)

variable.name: masking_mode
variable.description: image-based masking; set to drawing mode to create visible areas and enabled to use the mask
variable.note: masking only available in OpenGL renderer

subtable.name: clip_rect
subtable.description: constrain drawing to the specified area of the screen

subtable.name: world_rect
subtable.description: specifies the area of the screen for the 3D game view

subtable.name: map_rect
subtable.description: specifies the area of the screen for the overhead map

subtable.name: term_rect
subtable.description: specifies the area of the screen for displaying terminals

subtable.name: text_margins
subtable.description: specifies margins from the edges of the world_rect for drawing text such as Lua overlays, messages, and the input console

function.name: fill_rect
function.description: draws a solid rectangle to the screen

function.name: frame_rect
function.description: draws an outlined rectangle to the screen
function.note: the outline is drawn entirely inside the given bounds

variable.name: scale
variable.description: scale factor, for resizing specific bitmap font sizes
variable.note: it's usually better to create a new font at the correct size instead

function.name: measure_text
function.description: returns the width and height of a string when drawn in this font

function.name: draw_text
function.description: draws a string to the screen
function.note: transparency only available in OpenGL renderer

argument.name: file
argument.description: the path to a TTF file, for the standard variant of the font (the special path "mono" indicates the default Mono Sans font) [default: "mono"]

argument.name: style
argument.description: a number indicating the sum of any font styles to use (1 - bold; 2 - italic; 4 - underline) [default: 0]

argument.name: id
argument.description: a resource ID from the Fonts file (for the default Fonts file, valid values are 4 for Monaco and 22 for Courier)

argument.name: style
argument.description: a number indicating the sum of any font styles to use (1 - bold; 2 - italic; 4 - underline) [default: 0]

variable.name: width
variable.description: width of the image in pixels

variable.name: height
variable.description: height of the image in pixels

variable.name: unscaled_width
variable.description: width of the image before any calls to :rescale()

variable.name: unscaled_height
variable.description: height of the image before any calls to :rescale()

subtable.name: crop_rect
subtable.description: specifies a portion of the image to be drawn

variable.name: tint_color
variable.description: scale the color and opacity by this value when drawing

variable.name: rotation
variable.description: degrees to rotate the image when drawn
variable.note: axis of rotation is about the center of the drawn area

argument.name: mask
argument.description: the path to an image file to use as an opacity mask
